title: The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives
descriptions: The grant proposal, titled "The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives," aims to delve into the stress, overload, and disorders associated with modernity in the nineteenth century through the lens of literature, science, and medicine, with Benjamin Ward Richardson's Diseases of Modern Life (1876) serving as a foundational framework. The project will focus on various areas such as diseases stemming from worry and mental strain, lifestyle diseases like alcohol and narcotics abuse, environmental pollution diseases, diseases of finance and speculation, among others. The objectives include tracing the circulation of ideas across literature, science, and medicine, exploring the interconnections between physiological, psychological, and social health or disease, and offering fresh perspectives on contextualizing modernity's challenges. Methodologies will center around a holistic and integrative Victorian vision, supported by cross-disciplinary scholarship. Anticipated outcomes include advancing scholarship in uncharted territories and making breakthroughs in breaking down the compartmentalization of psychiatric, environmental, or literary history. By shedding light on these historical perspectives, this project has the potential to offer valuable insights into the roots of contemporary health issues and societal challenges.
